title: Which NFL QB class is better: 2018 or 2020?
text:
The NFL is officially in it’s newest era of top-end play at the quarterback position. The battles of Peyton Manning, Tom Brady, Drew Brees, Matt Ryan, Phillip Rivers and others are officially over. The position moved in a younger almost instantly, with players such as Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, Josh Allen and Joe Burrow dominating the league.
Because the position is younger, many of these star players shared draft classes and were picked right in front or after each other in the NFL draft. Two quarterback draft classes stick out by each producing several of the most dominant players in the league.
The 2018 NFL quarterback class featured Baker Mayfield, Sam Darnold, Josh Allen, Josh Rosen, and Lamar Jackson. The 2020 NFL quarterback class featured Joe Burrow, Tua Tagovailoa, Justin Herbert, Jordan Love, and Jalen Hurts.
The quarterback position can take years to develop. However, these two classes have already proven their ability to deliver high-reward low-risk football.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(gt)
library(janitor)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)

rawqb2 <- read_csv("qbs19752024.csv")

mvpqbclass <- rawqb2 |> 
   filter(Player %in% c("Lamar Jackson", "Baker Mayfield", "Josh Rosen", "Sam Darnold", "Josh Allen")) |>
  group_by(Player) |> 
  arrange(desc(Player))

sbqbclass <- rawqb2 |> 
   filter(Player %in% c("Joe Burrow", "Tua Tagovailoa", "Justin Herbert", "Jordan Love", "Jalen Hurts")) |>
  group_by(Player) |> 
  arrange(desc(Player))

allqbs <- rawqb2 |> 
   filter(Player %in% c("Joe Burrow", "Tua Tagovailoa", "Justin Herbert", "Jordan Love", "Jalen Hurts", "Lamar Jackson", "Baker Mayfield", "Josh Rosen", "Sam Darnold", "Josh Allen")) |>
  group_by(Player) |> 
  arrange(desc(Player))

mvpqbclassdumbbell <- mvpqbclass |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  summarise(
    CareerPassTD = sum(TD),
    CareerInt = sum(Int), 
    CareerGames = sum(G)
  ) |>
  mutate(
    PassTDPerGame = CareerPassTD/CareerGames,
    IntPerGame = CareerInt/CareerGames
  )

sbqbclassdumbbell <- sbqbclass |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  summarise(
    CareerPassTD = sum(TD),
    CareerInt = sum(Int), 
    CareerGames = sum(G)
  ) |>
  mutate(
    PassTDPerGame = CareerPassTD/CareerGames,
    IntPerGame = CareerInt/CareerGames)

sbdb <- ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=sbqbclassdumbbell, 
    aes(y=reorder(Player,PassTDPerGame), x=IntPerGame, xend=PassTDPerGame),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "red",
    colour_xend = "darkgreen")+
  labs(
    x= "2020 QB Class",
    y="",
  )
 
mvpdb <- ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=mvpqbclassdumbbell, 
    aes(y=reorder(Player,PassTDPerGame), x=IntPerGame, xend=PassTDPerGame),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "red",
    colour_xend = "darkgreen")+
  labs(
    x= "2018 QB Class",
    y="",
  )
  
mvpdb + sbdb +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Which QB class delivers the most while hurting you the least?",
    subtitle = "The 2020 class has five quarterbacks that throw more touchdowns than interceptions, unlike the 2018 class.",
    caption = "Pro Football Reference | By Thomas Thorpe"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









Young quarterbacks also bring a lot of uncertainty to the field. One of the only ways to predict what a quarterback can consistently deliver is to look at the long term trend. These two quarterback classes have shown their consistency and expected results for years.


Code
incmvp <- mvpqbclass |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  mutate(
    Inc = Att-Cmp
  )

passingstatsmvp <- incmvp |> 
 group_by(Player) |> 
  summarise(
    CareerCmp = sum(Cmp),
    CareerInc = sum(Inc),
    CareerAtt = sum(Att),
    CareerPassYds = sum(PassingYds),
    CareerGames = sum(G)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    CareerCompPct = CareerCmp/CareerAtt,
    CareerPassYdsPerGame = CareerPassYds/CareerGames) 

rosenpassing <- passingstatsmvp |> 
  filter(Player == "Josh Rosen")

lamarpassing <- passingstatsmvp |> 
  filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

mvpplot <- ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=passingstatsmvp, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame, size=))+
  annotate("rect", fill = "green", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = .64, xmax = Inf,
        ymin = 200, ymax = Inf) +
  geom_point(data=rosenpassing, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame))+
  geom_text(aes(x=.55, y=125, label="Josh Rosen"), color = "red", size = 3)+
  geom_point(data=lamarpassing, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame))+
  geom_text(aes(x=.637, y=190, label="Lamar Jackson"), color = "darkgreen", size = 3)+
  labs(
    x="2018 QB Class", 
    y="")

incsb <- sbqbclass |> 
  group_by(Player) |> 
  mutate(
    Inc = Att-Cmp
  )

passingstatssb <- incsb |> 
 group_by(Player) |> 
  summarise(
    CareerCmp = sum(Cmp),
    CareerInc = sum(Inc),
    CareerAtt = sum(Att),
    CareerPassYds = sum(PassingYds),
    CareerGames = sum(G)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    CareerCompPct = CareerCmp/CareerAtt,
    CareerPassYdsPerGame = CareerPassYds/CareerGames)

burrowpassing <- passingstatssb |> 
  filter(Player == "Joe Burrow")

hurtspassing <- passingstatssb |> 
  filter(Player == "Jalen Hurts")

sbplot <- ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=passingstatssb, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame, size=))+
  annotate("rect", fill = "green", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = .64, xmax = Inf,
        ymin = 200, ymax = Inf) +
  geom_text(aes(x=.665, y=235, label="Good Player Zone"), size=5)+
  geom_point(data=burrowpassing, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame))+
  geom_text(aes(x=.6815, y=272, label="Joe Burrow"), color = "darkgreen", size = 3)+
  geom_point(data=hurtspassing, aes(x=CareerCompPct, y=CareerPassYdsPerGame))+
  geom_text(aes(x=.639, y=198, label="Jalen Hurts"), color = "red", size = 3)+
  labs(
    x="2020 QB Class", 
    y="")

mvpplot + sbplot +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Which QB class is easier to trust when throwing the football?",
    subtitle = "Nearly the entirety of the 2020 QB class does more through the air.",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By Thomas Thorpe"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )+
  theme_minimal()









Young quarterbacks are also under pressure until they start to prove their talents in stressful situations. These two classes are already proving they can handle the moment when the game’s on the line.


Code
mvpqbcomebacks <- mvpqbclass |>
  summarise(
    sum(GWD)
  )

sbqbcomebacks <- sbqbclass |> 
  summarise(
    sum(GWD)
  )

mvpqbcomebacks <- c("Game Winnging Drives" = 58)
sbqbcomebacks <- c("Game Winnging Drives" = 52, 6)

iron(
  waffle(
    mvpqbcomebacks, 
        rows = 5, 
        title="The 2018 QB Class", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 game winning drive", 
        colors = c("black")
      )+
    labs(
      x="The 2018 QB Class",
      title = "Which QB class has more success in crunch time?",
      subtitle = "The 2018 QB class is slightly ahead of the younger 2020 class."
    )+
    theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size=16, face = "bold"),
      axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
      axis.title.y = element_blank()
    ),
  waffle(
    sbqbcomebacks,
      rows = 5,
      title="The 2020 QB Class", 
      xlab="1 square = 1 game winning drive",
      colors = c("red","white")
  )+
  labs(
      x="The 2020 QB Class",
      caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | Thomas Thorpe"
    )
  )
